problem.tex: Let $a\in G$ for some region $G$. Suppose $f$ is continuous on $G$ and analytic on $G\setminus\{a\}$. Prove $f$ is analytic at $a$.

solution.tex: Assume $f$ is not constant, for the result is trivial if it is. Using translations and rescalings we can assume, without loss of generality, that $G=\mathbb{D}$, $a=0$, and there is some $M>0$ such that $|f(z)|<M$ for all $|z|<1$. Note $f'$ is defined on $\mathbb{D}^*=\mathbb{D}\setminus\{0\}$. First we produce a bound for $f'$ near $0$. Let $a$ have $0<|a|<\frac{1}{2}$ and let $\gamma$ trace out the circle $|z-a|=\frac{|a|}{2}$. By Cauchy's integral formula \[|f'(a)|=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)^2}dz\right|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\frac{|f(z)|}{|z-a|^2}|dz|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\frac{M}{\frac{|a|^2}{4}}2\pi\frac{|a|}{2}=\frac{2M}{|a|}.\] Let $g:\mathbb{D}^*\to\mathbb{C}$ be defined by \[g(z)=z^2f(z).\] Then for any $z$ with $0<|z|<1$, \[g'(z)=2zf(z)+z^2f'(z).\] By the bound produced above, $z^2f'$ and therefore $g'$ is continuous at $0$ (taking $0$ to $0$). Then $g$ is analytic on the disc. Moreover both $g$ and $g'$ vanish at the origin, so $g$ has a root of order at least 2 there. By the degree argument there is a natural number $d\geq2$ and an analytic $h$ such that \[g(z)=z^dh(z)\] on all of $\mathbb{D}$. Then $f=z^{d-2}h$, so $f$ is analytic on $\mathbb{D}$.
